text: Hello.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I'm Avel Guédin-Carrieux.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I work with Andy Clark, who is a cognitive philosopher at the University of Sussex.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: in the context of the X-CAPE project, which is a project on cognitive archaeology, which focuses on the relation between mind and material culture.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm also a founding member of CAIRO's scientific para-academicalisation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Let's think of it as a think tank.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And what I will present today, let us consider it as an advertisement for the social science sub-project in the Acton Institute.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: because it's the aggregation of the work I did to motivate, well, necessity for, I will say, new mathematics for the study of social change that are inspired by Active Inference, but not really in line with what is done mathematically to formalize it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we will go from contextuality to constraints, and I will try to articulate an Active Inference ontology for participatory realism and social change.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: First, let us try to motivate what is it that we are doing here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, human minds and human culture display a very clear sign of open-ended evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What do I mean by open-ended evolution?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It is evolution that is open-ended.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I'm sorry, this is kind of circular.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Essentially, you can make new things that did not exist before, that were not a thing before, that were not a part of some platonic space of things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We made it up.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It was made up.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is what I mean by open-ended evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is true in generally whatever it is that you might do.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, for example, we have an impression of a space landscape on the left of the screen.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And, you know, it's buildings.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We made them up.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We built those buildings and they ensured a specific perception of what a building is that did not predate the concept of a building, the invention of building by humans.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is very manifest, for example, in writing because, you know, writing is a sign.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The entire activity of writing relies on signs being a thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But signs are a thing only if we look at them as signs.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we are looking at letters on this screen and understand them as being embedded with meaning.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But the concept of a C does not pre-exist humanity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There is no C dimension in the universal wave function at Big Bang.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We've got it up.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's a part of the evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the problem of explaining, presenting, addressing mathematically and physically the open-ended evolution of stuff, it's a pretty huge problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Stuart Kaufman, best physics guy, in my opinion, dedicated his career to that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And let's be frank, he did not solve it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He is not near to solving it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Because it's a hard problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Because there is this idea that
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Open-ended change brings out new stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: In mathematics, we have to represent a nice space that has specific possibilities in it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Else, we are not going far.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this seems to be incoherent with the logic of open-ended evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, hard problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I will jump to cognitive science because, again, my interest here is in human mind and social evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I will try to explain what we mean by explaining in cognitive science.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So for schematic purposes, I will say there are three kinds of explanation that we can go for.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: One is nomological, it's with regard to laws.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So for example, if I, I don't know, throw a thing and see that it falls this way, I can formulate a law that describes what happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And because it happens a lot, it happens every time I try,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I claim it is a law.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I claim that describing the regularity explains this activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So it's a phenomenological approach to explanation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I just described the phenomena and hope this is explanatory.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is how we do things in physics, not in psychology, not in biology, not in cognitive science, not in sociology.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What is more natural in those disciplines, the special sciences, is a mechanical explanation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we look at structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: and we show how this structure entails this phenomenon.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, we have the Hodgkin-Oxley model of neural activity, which postulates a bunch of electrochemistry, which, if verified, and it seems to be verified, explains the action potential activity of neurons.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I would say pretty close to mechanical explanation in the space of possible explanation are functional explanations, which address not
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: does it work but why is it and that is centered on you know functional hypothesis so it's for example most of what biologists evolutionary biologists do it's adaptive hypothesis what why must this happen because it's selected for
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I would say both you can cluster those approaches between homological, where you tend to try to describe laws, and mechanical and functional hypothesis, where you will have a more lean approach to modeling and trying to get into what is going on in a specific system for it to act like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And in neuroscience, we are pretty good at mechanisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is according to Brun and Piccinini.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: the hallmark of what they call cognitive neuroscience.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We assume that the behavior, as we can ensure it, derives from cognitive mechanisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Those cognitive mechanisms are implemented by the physical structure of the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this physical structure is integrated in a context of operation that involves both physiological and ecological factors.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we can look at, for example, activation, patterns of activation in brain activity, and map them into an equation here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's from DOMATOB, and it tries to map brain activity onto reinforcement learning, which is a very hype family, was at least a very hype family of algorithms describing learning.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we can explain activity from structure, but what we cannot do with a mechanistic approach is explain why the structure is there, because
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: you can describe, you can explain activity from structure, but if you try to explain structure from structure, you get, you know, regression to infinity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You do not explain much, or at least you do not have the possibility to explain without regressing to the infinite.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The argument I will make here is that both cognitive structure, understood as, you know, patterns in cognitive activity, and its evolution,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: flow from a single phenomena, which is the construction of meaning to cognitive agency.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the structure produces a function, a part of activity, which itself will shape the structure at time t plus one.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is the only way I can think of to at least have a baseline concept of what it is to study operand evolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: System does stuff.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Stuff changes system.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Pretty simple.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I don't see how we could go around that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And to be more precise, I will argue that we exist in a context that is characterized by social constraints and that define what we agree, let us say, we can and cannot do in a given social context.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And these constraints are integrated and enacted by humans.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the way they are integrated and enacted kind of ontologically by construction leads to their reconstruction.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is what underlies both the structure of cognition through the integration of thinking in those systems of constraints and the open-ended evolution thereof.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we do active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is the Active Inference Institute.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We may as well explain active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Well, I guess most people who are attending to the talk now know what I'm talking about, but this is going on YouTube.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I will reference it.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I need to explain what active inference is.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Active inference is built from what Karl Freestone and colleagues proposed as a principle for cognition that is Bayesian inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Bayesian inference basically reduces to the formula you see on screen the probability of an hypothesis given an evidence
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: is equal to the probability of an evidence given an hypothesis times the probability of the hypothesis over the probability of evidence.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, for example, if you hear barking, it's pretty likely there is a dog.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Unless it's very likely there is a dog near you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, you are in an office and the office is closed, so no dog can enter.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Or unless you have other explanation for hearing barking.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: For example, you have a
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: YouTube tab open with eight hours of barking noises.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I don't know why you would, but if you did, you would hear barking and not think of a dog.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So this reduces to this formula.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: P of E knowing H means the probability of hearing barking if there is a dog.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Probability of H means probability of having a dog with you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Probability of E means probability of hearing the barking.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: you can compute the probability of having a dog with you, knowing that you heard barking from that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: This is the most basic stuff you can do with statistics.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And the thing is, there is no reason why your brain or any single natural system for that matter could compute this, because neurons do action potential, they don't do numbers.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So the novelty in Fritz's approach is to propose an algorithm, well, more of a physical process that could approach optimal Bayesian inference, so the optimal inference of hypothesis given evidence, through minimization of something called rational free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You don't need to know exactly what this formula is.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What is important is that it's something that is always higher
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: to surprise.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you minimize your energy, you minimize surprise, you approach a perfect Bayesian model of what is going on around you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And if you assume that your activity layer upon layer upon layer of your activity, self-organize like that to infer the causes of sensory stimuli,
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: they will effectively predict upcoming signal in a way that enables adaptive understanding and navigation of the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is pretty much what the active inference paradigm is.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: It's assuming that the brain does that.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We will not try to illustrate what exactly we mean by active inference predictive processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: how things move.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01
